STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 2, 2021
Linda Needham
Monroe County DHHS
903 S Telegraph Road
Monroe, MI 48161
RE: License #: CP580201306
Monroe County DHHS
903 S Telegraph Road
Monroe, MI 48161
Dear Ms. Needham:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 05/13/21.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Implementation, Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days
from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat noncompliance, identify why the previous CAP was
unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Kari Muntean, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 395-0920
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP580201306
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Elizabeth Hertel, Designee
Name of Facility: Monroe County DHHS
Facility Address: 903 S Telegraph Road
Monroe, MI 48161
Facility Telephone #: (734) 243-7203
Original Issuance Date: 07/01/1989
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): Virtual entrance: 03/09/21; Onsite: 03/11/21; Virtual pre-exit:
05/13/21

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12209 Orientation and training.
(1) An agency shall ensure and document that each social
service worker and each social service supervisor receives not
less than 16 hours of orientation after initial appointment and
before assumption of assigned duties.
Two of eleven employee files reviewed were found to have their orientation
documentation completed several months after hire.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(b) A copy of the job description for the staff member's
current position.
Two of eleven employee files reviewed were found to have their job description
completed several months after hire.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
One of three borrowed bed files reviewed was found not to have signed the parent
agency agreement until three days after placement.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
4

(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as soon as
is indicated, based on the information received, but not later
than 7 calendar days after receipt of the information.
One of three special evaluations reviewed did not clearly identify how the evaluation
was initiated.
R 400.12403 Policy and procedures.
(2) The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of the
following areas:
(i) Service plans.
The following service plan signatures were found in non-compliance with the
agency’s policy:
 Four of six foster care files were found to be missing caregiver/provider
signatures or did not have uploaded signatures.
 Two of three applicable foster care files were found to have missing, undated,
late, or not uploaded parental signatures on treatment plans.
 Three of six foster care files reviewed were found to each have one late
supervisory signature (beyond the 14 days allowed). These were noted to be
one, one, and three days late respectively.
All of the above are noted to be REPEAT VIOLATIONS, Renewal Report, 03/29/20
and corresponding CAP, 04/15/20, and Interim Report, 05/16/19, and
corresponding CAP, 05/24/19. The agency must report on why the previous CAPs
failed and how they are going to ensure compliance.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent, then the reason
why return is not possible.
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed with a
relative, then the reason why those placements are not
possible.
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R 400.12404(4).
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child’s age,
appropriate to the child’s capacity to understand, which includes
an explanation to all relevant parties as to why the change is
necessary.
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the change in
placement.
5

(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R 400.12417
(h) The child’s new location and address.
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing of the
following information:
(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of the change,
except when prior notification would jeopardize the child’s care
or safety. If prior notice is not provided, then the agency shall
notify the foster parent, at the time of the change, why prior
notice was not given.
(ii) Of the current foster parent’s rights concerning the change in
placement.
(j) Supervisory approval before the change.
(4) If an emergency change in placement is necessary, then all
of the documentation required in subrules (2) and (3) of this rule
shall be in the child’s record within 14 calendar days after the
change in placement.
Three of three applicable foster care files reviewed for change of placement were
found to have late and missing DHHS 69 forms to document the change in
placement. Out of eight total changes in placement, one DHHS 69 was missing and
seven were late. One of the seven was also unsigned. REPEAT VIOLATIONS,
Renewal Report, 03/29/20 and corresponding CAP, 04/15/20, and Interim Report,
05/16/19, and corresponding CAP, 05/24/19. The agency must report on why the
previous CAPs failed and how they are going to ensure compliance.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
One of three applicable foster care files reviewed was found to have a late initial
service plan. The plan was observed to be 11 days late.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at least once
every month.
(d) Provisions for visits between siblings who are not placed
together except when there is a court determination that visits
are detrimental to either child.
6

(b) One of six foster care files was found to be missing one monthly face to face visit
with the child in the caregiver/provider home.
(d) One applicable foster care file reviewed for sibling visitation did not document
sibling visits monthly.
R 400.12422 Foster care record.
(3) The record shall contain all of the following information:
(e) Change of placement documentation as required by R
400.12405.
One of four closed foster care files reviewed was found to have completed the
DHHS 69 late for the closure. REPEAT VIOLATIONS, Renewal Report, 03/29/20 and
corresponding CAP, 04/15/20, and Interim Report, 05/16/19, and corresponding
CAP, 05/24/19. The agency must report on why the previous CAPs failed and how
they are going to ensure compliance.
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
One of two applicable independent living files did not contain documentation that the
program statement was provided to the youth before placement in independent
living.
R 400.12503 Policies and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency’s policies and procedures required by this
rule.
One of two applicable independent living files did not contain documentation that the
policies and procedures were provided to the youth.
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service
worker and the youth in independent living at least once
each month at a youth's place of residence.
7

(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is
complying with the terms of the contract required by R
400.125010, continues to reside in a safe and
acceptable environment, and is managing expenditures.
(a) One of three independent living files did not document all monthly face to face
contacts. There were two missing contacts for this file.
(b) Two of three independent living files were found to have missing monthly budge
reviews.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(n) Change of placement documentation as required by
R 400.12405.
One of two applicable independent living files reviewed for change of placement was
found to have one missing and one late DHHS 69 to document the change.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Two of three independent living files were found to each be missing one quarterly
contract. REPEAT VIOLATIONS, Renewal Report, 03/29/20 and corresponding
CAP, 04/15/20, and Interim Report, 05/16/19, and corresponding CAP, 05/24/19.
The agency must report on why the previous CAPs failed and how they are going
to ensure compliance.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements reviewed.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
8

DHHS Policy FOM 801 Medical Passports
Four of six foster care files and one of three independent living files were observed
to have missing, and/or late medical passports.
REPEAT VIOLATIONS, Renewal Report, 03/29/20 and corresponding CAP,
04/15/20, and Interim Report, 05/16/19, and corresponding CAP, 05/24/19. The
agency must report on why the previous CAPs failed and how they are going to
ensure compliance.
DHHS Policy 722-03C OLDER YOUTH: PREPARATION, PLACEMENT, AND
DISCHARGE
Three of three independent living files did not contain Casey Life Skills
Assessments as required.
DHHS Policy - FOM 722-06H CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH PARENT(S)/
GUARDIAN(S)
One of three applicable foster care files was found to be missing a quarterly
parental home visit.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH CHILD IN OUT-
OF-HOME PLACEMENT
One of three independent living files reviewed did not document two face to face
contacts with the youth in the first two months of two separate placement changes.
One face to face contact was missing for each change.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER CONTACTS
Three of six foster care files and two of three independent living files were found
to have entered social work contacts late (beyond the five days permitted). These
contacts were observed to be between one and 26 days late.
REPEAT VIOLATIONS, Renewal Report, 03/29/20 and corresponding CAP,
04/15/20, and Interim Report, 05/16/19, and corresponding CAP, 05/24/19. The
agency must report on why the previous CAPs failed and how they are going
to ensure compliance.
DHHS Policy 722-06B - Family Team Meetings.
Five of six foster care files and three of three independent living files were found
to have missing and/or late and/or not uploaded Family Team Meeting reports.
REPEAT VIOLATIONS, Renewal Report, 03/29/20 and corresponding CAP,
04/15/20, and Interim Report, 05/16/19, and corresponding CAP, 05/24/19. The
agency must report on why the previous CAPs failed and how they are going to
ensure compliance.
9

DHHS Policy FOM 722-07F Annual Review/Change Form
One applicable independent living file found not to have completed an annual
update to the DHHS-643, (Permanency Goal Review) from the point that the goal
was changed to PPFWR & APPLA.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 309
The agency was advised that they need to follow up on submitted criminal
clearances to ensure processing and uploading for adult household members.
R 413
The agency is advised to follow up with the health liaison and/or doctor’s office to
obtain a medical exam for one foster youth. The visit was observed in MiSACWIS
and on the medical passport, but the document has not been uploaded.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
No additional consultation was requested.
10

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted no acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
There are 21 violations noted in this report, as compared to 17 in the last Renewal
Report. Of those violations, there are 7 repeat violations for which the agency will
need to provide a robust CAP to address the current and past violations. The
administrators and supervisors reported that difficulty of adapting to the pandemic
and working remotely contributed to stressors among workers. The Field Analyst
report noted no safety concerns for follow up.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
May 24, 2021
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 2, 2021
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
